docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A privacy amendment should include the right to ''life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness,'' with one addition: ''only when without harm to others.''

headline.main: Bringing Privacy Out in the Open

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     A privacy amendment should include the right to ''life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness,'' with one addition: ''only when without harm to others.''

docs.lead_paragraph: MIA PETERSON is not a fan of tests. Because she has Down syndrome, she says, she cannot always think as fast as she would like to and tests end up making her feel judged. A recent driving test, for instance, ended in frustration. Ms. Peterson, 31, the chief of self-advocacy for the National Down Syndrome Society, prefers public speaking and travel. And her test aversion extends to the latest one designed to detect Down in a fetus. ''I don't want to think like we're being judged against,'' Ms. Peterson said. ''Not meeting their expectations.''

headline.main: The Problem With an Almost-Perfect Genetic World

docs.snippet: For people with Down syndrome and the cluster of other conditions subject to prenatal screening, the latest test to detect Down in a fetus comes with a certain chill.

multimedia.credit: Given the increasing age of birthmothers, the number of Down syndromebirths should be increasing, accordingto experts projections. Instead, a studyhas found that the total has declined.
multimedia.caption: Fewer Born With Down Syndrome

docs.lead_paragraph: Sure, Always Blaming The Consumer Culture The flashbulbs were vexing for NORMAN MAILER, who grimaced and swatted away the photographers like KING KONG with the biplanes, albeit a smaller, cuddlier King Kong wearing a tuxedo. It was the National Book Awards ceremony, and we were at the Marriott Marquis.
docs.snippet: It was the National Book Awards ceremony, and we were at the Marriott Marquis.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON; With Caroline Palmer and Joe Brescia

docs.lead_paragraph: When is it a good idea for an adolescent to take a sleeping pill? There is reason to suppose the answer may be never. No prescription sleep aids are approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in people under 18, largely because they have not been well studied in children.

headline.main: Doctors Ponder Drugs for Sleepless Nights of Adolescence

docs.snippet: To some extent, not sleeping enough is a normal part of adolescence. But even cautious physicians say that sleeping pills sometimes make sense.

docs.lead_paragraph: Top federal drug officials decided to reject an application to allow over-the-counter sales of the morning-after pill months before a government scientific review of the application was completed, according to accounts given to Congressional investigators. The Government Accountability Office, a nonpartisan investigative arm of Congress, concluded in a report released Monday that the Food and Drug Administration's May 2004 rejection of the morning-after pill, or emergency contraceptive, application was unusual in several respects.

headline.main: REPORT DETAILS F.D.A. REJECTION OF NEXT-DAY PILL

docs.abstract: Government Accountability Office report cites several unusual aspects of Food and Drug Administration's May 2004 rejection of morning-after pill application; says rejection of pill, called Plan B, was announced even before government scientific review of application was completed, and that top agency officials were deeply involved in decision; says officials' decision to ignore recommendation of independent advisory committee as well as agency's own scientific review staff is unprecedented; concludes that top official's 'novel' rationale for rejecting application contradicts past agency practices; Sens Patty Murray and Hillary Rodham Clinton issue statement saying GAO report confirms that FDA decision was 'politically motivated' and came down from 'highest levels at the FDA'; although FDA has concluded that Plan B is contraceptive, some abortion opponents consider pill tantamount to ending pregnancy; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Government Accountability Office said it was told the decision came before a scientific review was completed.
